qas.question: Who controlled Iraq before the Arabs?
Who ruled Syria before it was conquered by the followers of Muhammad?
What book never mentioned racial equality?
What was encouraged in the Quran?
What started to resurface before Muhammad's passing?
Who was soft on the governors?
What area wanted the capital of the Islamic State to be outside their area?

context: <b3_0>The Quran<b3_0/> and Muhammad talked about racial equality and justice as in The Farewell Sermon. <b4_0>Tribal and nationalistic differences<b4_0/> were discouraged. But after Muhammad's passing, the <b5_0>old tribal differences<b5_0/> between the Arabs started to resurface. Following the Roman–Persian Wars and the Byzantine–Sassanid Wars, deep rooted differences between Iraq, formally under the <a0_0>Persian Sassanid Empire<a0_0/>, and <b7_0>Syria<b7_0/>, formally under the <a1_0>Byzantine Empire<a1_0/>, also existed. Each wanted the capital of the newly established Islamic State to be in their area. Previously, the second caliph <a2_0><b6_0>Umar<b6_0/><a2_0/> was very firm on the governors and his spies kept an eye on them. If he felt that a governor or a commander was becoming attracted to wealth, he had him removed from his position.
